results.title: The Land = Al Ard
results.creator_credit: Youssef Chahine and Mustapha Abdel Aziz
results.brief_description: Set in British colonised Egypt during the 1930s and adapted from the novel of the same name by Abdel Rahman Al-Sharqawi, director Youssef Chahine (An Egyptian story, Alexandria trilogy, Cairo station) spent eight years in the making of this classic film about the struggles and division of a small peasant village in their battle with Cairo-based bureaucracy and government. Living under harsh conditions, the villagers find themselves fighting each other over water irrigation rights that have been cut by half by the government. But more threatening to the farming community than losing their water rights are the plans of a wealthy local landowner intent on building himself a palatial home with modern roads cutting right through the villagers’ land. Just what will it take to unite the village community? A contemplative film of rural life, customs and rituals, political oppression, family, marriage and relationships, and a rich array of characters who provide the film with a level of depth, humour and sensitivity. Cast includes Yehia Chahine, Ezzat El-Alaili, Ali El-Scherif, Mahmoud El-Meliguy, Imad Hamdi, Nagwa Ibrahim. Nominated for the Golden Palm Award at the 1970 Cannes Film Festival and also named as the best Egyptian film ever made in a recent poll of Egyptian film critics. In Arabic with English subtitles. NB: Images and sound of variable quality.

results.title: Gaza Strip
results.brief_description: James Longely’s “Gaza Strip” documents the lives of Palestinians living inside the cramped Israeli territory. Filmed in the context of the second Intifada in September 2000 and prior to the election of far rightwing Likud leader Ariel Sharon, what follows is a narrative loosely based around the 13 year old Mohammed Hejazzi. Mohammed’s education was short lived due to the dependency on him as sole provider for his household. The loss of childhood innocence is captured by powerful scenes of the boy hurling stones at the surrounding Israeli occupied territories following the death of his close friend by Israeli gunfire. Through Mohammed’s eyes are seen the crowding caused by illegal Israeli settlements, the use of neurological gas against civilians, the fallout caused by unexploded artillery, the constant influx of ambulance vehicles and hospital queues. Much of “Gaza Strip” unfolds through gripping and powerful images without the use of lengthy interviews or a political dialogue, but rather startling audiovisual bites of the daily struggle within Gaza. Perhaps the most moving and disturbing moment in “Gaza” is the admission of an infant child contemplating the life of a martyr. “Gaza Strip” is Longley’s first feature. In Arabic with English subtitles.

results.title: Chronicle of a disappearance [NTSC]
results.brief_description: Formally daring within its rigorous and restrained aesthetic, Palestinian director Elia Suleiman’s episodic, elliptical cinematic essay about what it meant to be a Palestinian in the Occupied Territories in 1996, is constructed in two parts. “Nazareth, A Personal Diary”, set in Suleiman’s birthplace, renders a series of vignettes of everyday life with its rounds of boredom, solitude, complaint, conviviality, and often surreal contradiction. Characters wander in and out of the film, essentially writing their own diary entries. Part two “Jerusalem, A Political Diary” features Suleiman himself as a deadpan internal exile observing events around him: rampant, chaotic tourism in the Holy Land, and the terrors of partition and paranoia which culminate in a personal encounter with the Israeli army during a house raid which is both scary and absurd. According to Suleiman, the film depicts ‘a situation of stasis, characterised by deprivation, disillusionment, and lack of action’. Angry, sad, witty and tender, the film does not provide distinct answers to questions of Palestinian identity. Rather it offers an assortment of possible truths as it explores, through Suleiman’s own eyes, the effects of ghettoisation and marginalisation on the Palestinian psyche. The film won the Best First Feature Award at Venice Film Festival in 1996. In Arabic with English subtitles.

results.title: The Marriage of the blessed = Arusi-ye khuban [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Mohsen Makhmalbaf and Farabi Cinema Foundation
results.brief_description: This is an extremely confronting and at times disturbing film exploring the psychological torture of a shell-shocked war photojournalist and his attempts to come to grips with reality on returning home from the Iran-Iraq war front. After spending some time rehabilitating in a hospital mental asylum in Tehran, Haji (Mahmud Bigham) is finally released to the care of his fiancee Mehri (Roya Nonahali) and her family. However Haji is continually haunted with images of war and daily life becomes a struggle sending Haji into a downward spiral emotionally and psychologically. Mehri, who shares Haji’s passion for photography, tries in her own way to assist Haji in his recovery surrounding him with positive images of life whilst also pushing for their wedding ceremony to take place against her family’s wishes who now want to cancel the marriage. When Haji is given back his old job at the local newspaper, both he and Mehri take to the streets of Tehran with their cameras capturing images of the homeless, the drug addicts and prostitutes, and the oppressive poverty that exists post-revolution Iran. Haji’s boss, however, is not interested in social issues and refuses to print the photos leading to a tragic sequence of events for Haji and Mehri, and Haji’s eventual breakdown. Using evocative sounds and images, Makhmalbaf (Kandahar, Gabbeh) has created an amazing piece of experimental and controversial filmmaking in “The Marriage of the blessed” which for all its political and social commentary, managed to escape the religious censorship by the Iranian regime of the time. Cast includes Mohsen Zehtab, Ebrahim Abadi, Hossein Moslemi with cinemaphotography by Ali Reza Zarindest. In Farsi with English subtitles. NOTE: Contains disturbing war images.

results.title: The Mirror [Widescreen] [NTSC]
results.brief_description: After her mother fails to pick her up after school, a young Iranian girl with a broken arm (Mina Mohammed-Khani) sets off to find her own way home. As she traverses the bustling streets of Tehran, clogged with the press of people, traffic, and noise, she grows increasingly uncertain of her direction and the correct route. The everyday sounds, movements and interactions of city life are conveyed through her experiences as she encounters strangers both helpful and indifferent, rides on buses, and is confronted with rules regarding male and female behaviour. Midway through, the film takes a startling turn that breaks the audience’s engagement with the narrative and throws the constructed nature of this naturalistic documentation of city life into relief. The actor playing the young girl suddenly abandons her character declaring that she has had enough of acting and wants to go home. As she leaves the set the crew decide to keep filming as she undergoes a process almost identical to that of her character in her attempts to find her way home on her own. Rather than functioning as a distancing device, this shift offers an alternate version of a reality mediated by cinema. The focus on the filmmaking process itself and the use of non-actors and children in lead roles are all characteristic hallmarks of recent Iranian cinema. In Farsi with English subtitles.

results.title: Once upon a time, cinema [NTSC] = Nassereddin Shah, actor-e cinema
results.creator_credit: Mohsen Makhmalbaf and Masud Jafari Jozani
results.brief_description: Once again Iranian director Mohsen Makhmalbaf (The Marriage of the blessed, Gabbeh, Kandahar) has created an extraordinary piece of cinema with his tenth feature and first comedy. “Once upon a time, cinema” reflects on the history of Iranian cinema through the eyes of a Charlie Chaplin look-alike cinematographer whose main object in life is to bring the magic and fantasy of cinema to the Shah and his Persian court during the Qajar dynasty. Using excerpts from classic Iranian films, including “Gheisar (1969), “Still life” (1974), “Downpour” (1971) intercut with contemporary black and white footage, Makhmalbaf beautifully intertwines cinematic themes and genres from slapstick, melodrama and adventure to fantasy, surrealism and realism. The characters in the story consist of an eclectic mix, sometimes bordering on the bizarre, which only adds to the surreal tone of this intriguing and fascinating film. Cast includes Ezzatollah Entezami, Mahdi Hashemi, Mohammad Ali Keshavarz, Akbar Abdi, Dariush Arjomand, Faremah Motamed-Aria. (Awards: Istanbul; Karlovy Vary) In Farsi with English subtitles.

results.title: Pretty woman (Director's cut) [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Garry Marshall, Arnon Milchan, Steven Reuther, Silver Screen Partners IV and Touchstone Pictures
results.brief_description: Directed by Garry Marshall “Pretty woman” was the film that helped make a star of American actress Julia Roberts. Originally conceived as a film with a much darker tone, “Pretty woman” is a fairly light-hearted comedy. Edward Lewis, (Richard Gere) a businessman whose speciality is company takeovers, is on assignment in LA when he picks up a prostitute, Viv (Roberts), for the night. In the morning Lewis decides he likes what he sees and decides to hire Viv for a week’s round of polo parties and sex. Despite being somewhat gauche in her dress and manner, Viv is groomed for the part of the society lady, in a Pygmalion like transformation. Challenges ensue for the couple as they take a liking to one another beyond the bounds of their business arrangement. Each is drawn to the possibility that at the week’s end their partnership may blossom into a relationship. Also stars Laura San Giacomo as Viv’s housemate (also a prostitute) and Jason Alexander who plays Lewis’ sleazy lawyer. This special edition version of “Pretty woman” is the director’s cut.

results.title: Persona = Diabolic women = Masks [DVD]
results.brief_description: An actress’s nervous breakdown occasions her deliberate withdrawal into speechlessness. As a consequence she appears to break down her nurse’s confident personality. However, “Persona” cannot be summarised in terms of conventional plot. It is a virtual monologue in which language is presented as fraudulent. In Susan Sontag’s words, it is “a powerful instance of the motif of exchange. The actress creates a void by her silence. The nurse, by speaking, falls into it.” It is possible to interpret the first half of the film as naturalistic drama but following the disruption of the ‘terrifying caesura’ in the middle (which, like the opening, operates on the principle of intensity, not Brechtian detachment), the level of reality of each event is ambiguous, unresolved. Cast includes: Bibi Andersson, Liv Ullmann, Gunnar Bjornstrand. Photography by Sven Nykvist. In Swedish with English subtitles.

results.title: Divine intervention = Chronicle of love and pain [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Elia Suleiman, Humbert Balsan, Joachim Ortmanns, Arte France, Gimages, Lichtblick Filmproduktion, Ognon Pictures and Soread 2M
results.brief_description: The winner of the International Critic’s Prize at the 2002 Cannes Film Festival, “Divine Intervention” is a black comedy that utilises absurdist and surrealistic conventions to represent the psychological and political consequences of the Israeli occupation of Palestinian territories. A Palestinian filmmaker (played by director, Elia Suleiman), who lives in the Occupied Territories, is in love with an Arab woman who lives in Israel. Though they live in the same city, the consequences of occupation mean that they can only meet intermittently at the border checkpoints; and only always under the surveillance of Israeli soldiers. In the mean time, the film director has to contend with a dying father, a film script he is writing that will not settle into any defined order, and with his own fantasies of violence and despair. Around him, “Divine Intervention” situates Jewish, Muslim and Orthodox Christian communities in which tensions between neighbours, petty arguments and squabbles over relationships and personal histories, mirror the larger realities of war, occupation and terror. The audacious strengths of this exhilarating film lie in Suleiman’s ability to find the comic and the absurd in the most extreme and horrific of situations. Beginning with the slaughter of Santa Claus at the dawn of the current millennium, the film proceeds as a series of one-take tableaus, which appear initially random but which develop into an increasingly coherent artistic statement about loss, statehood and identity. “Divine Intervention” is a brave and unique expression of political cinema that finds apt cinematic metaphors for the terror, fear and violence that define the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

results.title: The 400 blows = Les Quatre cents coups
results.creator_credit: Francois Truffaut and Films du Carrosse
results.brief_description: Truffaut’s stunning first feature introduced his alter-ego Antoine Doinel. A chronicle of emotions and events the director experienced at first hand, the film is based, not on nostalgia, but on Truffaut’s painful memories of his childhood and adolescence. The camera is objective, the rhythms reflect the patterns and unpredictability of everyday life. However the apparently random series of episodes does have a cumulative effect encapsulated in the memorable final image. While a fierce critic of the state of French cinema in the fifties, Truffaut was not a revolutionary like Godard but sought to return in his first feature to what he saw as the best traditions of the French cinema represented by Vigo and Renoir (Rossellini’s Germany Year Zero and Hitchcock’s The Wrong Man were also important influences). The title refers to the French idiom, ‘to raise hell’. Cast includes: Jean-Pierre Leaud, Claire Maurier and Albert Remy.
